g.text: immediate implications for adaptation, this transition from stage 2 to stage 3 is key to the United Nations
Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) objective of avoiding dangerous interference with
the climate system (which remains relevant under the Paris agreement; Jacquet & Jamieson, 2016), since,
for example, a longer period of rapid warming represents a greater challenge to ecosystem adaptation.
Moreover, an improved understanding of this transition time will inform decision makers, such as water
resource planners, where climate uncertainty has important implications for large‚Äêscale infrastructure
investments over long lifetimes such as dams (Hallegatte, 2009; Keller et al., 2004).
We deÔ¨Åne TSC as the time when the warming rate is undetectably different from that which we anticipate
continuing for centuries (see Figure 1a and section 2). This demarcates the transition between the period of
high transience in which rapid warming accompanies increasing GHG concentrations (Rogelj et al., 2012)
and the period of steady change in which constant GHG concentrations lead to a signiÔ¨Åcantly reduced rate
While the ToE literature has identiÔ¨Åed regions where the anthropogenic signal will be Ô¨Årst detectable
(Hawkins & Sutton, 2012; Mahlstein et al., 2011), TSC provides a framework to characterize the length of
time required to transition to a near‚Äêconstant climate state as GHG approach stabilization and to identify
the regional disparities in the timing of this transition.
The remainder of this paper is organized as follows: In section 2 we describe the methods for quantifying
TSC. Section 3 provides a summary of General Circulation Model (GCM) data sets used to quantify TSC. In
section 4 we present the results of our analysis and section 5 provides a summary.
Suppose GHG concentrations continue to increase until year 2000 +
stabilize and are held constant for centuries. We let
be the rate of warming at year
, warming slows to a steady rate,
TSC is then deÔ¨Åned as the Ô¨Årst of
Due to natural variability in the climate system, background noise can obscure the warming signal, espe-
cially at small spatial scales. Therefore, to estimate a robust warming rate, we Ô¨Årst average the annual mean
temperature over a 5¬∞ √ó 5¬∞ grid cell resolution. Note that other spatial scales of aggregation have been tested
with aggregation over larger spatial scales leading to smaller values in
aged rates and Figure S2 in the supporting information (SI) for rates averaged over 20¬∞ √ó 20¬∞ grid cell).
Warming rates for each grid cell and each GCM are then estimated over a 50‚Äêyear moving window using
a modiÔ¨Åed version of the Theil‚ÄêSen bootstrap estimator (Sen, 1968): 10,000 pairs of points at least 10 years
apart are uniformly randomly sampled from the 50‚Äêyear window. We exclude pairs within 10 years so that
the sampled distribution of the warming rate reÔ¨Çects warming over decadal and longer time scales. Asample
size of 10,000 pairs of points was chosen for consistency across simulations. The median slope of the 10,000
pairs is the estimated warming rate for the year in the center of the 50‚Äêyear window. A 50‚Äêyear window was
chosen because it was the smallest window that produced similar estimates of TSC moving both forward in
time and backward in time. Rates are then smoothed using a 10‚Äêyear moving average. This results in yearly
estimated warming rates for 2031‚Äì2275 and 2036‚Äì2275 for the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project
We apply the TSC estimation framework to GCM simulations as follows:
is the MMM rate of warming averaged over the 23rd century (i.e.,
for rates between 2201 and 2275). The value
quantiÔ¨Åes the multimodel standard deviation of
to be 20 years to account for multidecadal oscillations that may affect the robustness of TSC. With
this selection, the earliest value of TSC could be 2051 and 2056 for CMIP3 and CMIP5, respectively.
